benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/allCustomFields - Retrieve account customFields

covered: Valid Request: Successful retrieval scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05) validate responses for required accountId and optional query parameters (objectType, audit).
Empty Response: TC06 and TC07 confirm the API returns HTTP 200 with an empty JSON array when no matching custom fields exist.

Query Parameters: Extensive parameter coverage — objectType and audit permutations (TC02, TC05, TC08, TC09), unsupported query param handling (TC10), single-parameter and partial-parameter cases (TC31), and invalid parameter formats (TC32, TC36).
Authorization / Authentication: TC14 and TC15 test missing and invalid authentication tokens returning HTTP 401.
Input validation & error codes: Account-id validation and error scenarios are covered (TC12 invalid format -> 400, TC13 non-existent -> 404, TC33/TC34/TC35 edge accountId cases).
Security: Injection and XSS handling are addressed (TC17 SQL injection handling, TC18 XSS invalid objectType handling) and tests assert no sensitive info leakage.
Schema & content validation: Multiple scenarios assert the response is a JSON array and that individual entries conform to the CustomField schema (TC01, TC02, TC05).

Resiliency, integration & regression: Service/unavailability and retry behaviors, dependency failures, regression checks and backward compatibility are covered (TC16, TC19, TC20, TC21, TC22, TC23, TC24, TC39).
Performance & scalability: Large dataset and performance-related scenarios exist (TC11 large number of fields, TC25 concurrent requests, TC26 high load).
Edge cases: Minimum/maximum counts and many edge input cases are present (TC29-TC36).
gaps: Pagination: No tests for pagination parameters or for APIs that page results (limit/offset/page headers, total-count, next/prev links). TC11 assumes all records are returned rather than validating paging semantics.
Caching behavior & HTTP headers: No assertions for Cache-Control, ETag, Last-Modified, conditional GET (If-None-Match) or 304 Not Modified handling; Content-Type header is not explicitly validated.
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests that assert 429 or throttle behavior under abusive request rates — TC25 covers concurrency/performance but not rate-limit enforcement semantics.
Authorization granularity (403): No tests for authenticated-but-unauthorized access (403) or role-based access controls if applicable.
Content negotiation & headers: No tests for Accept/Accept-Encoding variations, charset handling, or ensuring the response content-type is application/json with expected charset.
Explicit verification of audit default behavior: While audit enum values are tested, there is no explicit test asserting the default audit level (NONE) is returned when audit is omitted.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: if the API pages results, cover limit/offset or page tokens, boundary conditions (first/last page), and verify pagination-related headers (total count, next/prev links) and consistency when dataset changes between pages.
Add caching and conditional GET tests: assert Cache-Control and ETag headers, and add conditional requests using If-None-Match to validate 304 responses and cache behavior.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate high request rates to validate 429 responses, throttling headers (Retry-After), and client retry/backoff behavior.
Add authorization-granularity tests: cover authenticated-but-unauthorized (403) scenarios and any RBAC rules; verify error messages do not leak internals.
Assert response headers and content-type: add tests that explicitly check Content-Type: application/json (and charset), Content-Length, and any security headers (e.g., X-Content-Type-Options).
Add explicit audit-default test: validate that omitting audit returns the documented default (NONE) and that the presence/absence of audit metadata matches the requested level.
Harden error-message assertions: verify error payloads are user-friendly and consistent, and do not expose stack traces or sensitive internal details for all error paths (400/404/500/503).

If TC11 intends to validate very large result sets, replace the "return all records" assumption with pagination-aware validation or document and test for acceptable memory/response-size behavior and SLA under large payloads.
